ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned the basics of Ancient Greek, to the point where I can now slowly tackle most Greek texts with a dictionary and commentary.

This class offers a thorough and rigorous introduction to the intricacies of Ancient Greek grammar, supplemented by the professor's linguistic, etymological, and philological expertise. We concentrated on learning the basics of the language during the first half of the course, but by mid-spring we were reading Plato's Apology in the original Greek and analyzing the text with an eye to the syntactical, stylistic, philosophical, and historical details embedded throughout.

This is a one way ticket to reading Greek! You start with the alphabet and by the end of the course youve read through the apology.  You learn so much Greek grammar and reading a real text really helps show you the most common things to expect and to look out for going forward. If you want to go from no Greek knowledge to an intermediate level this is the course for you!
How to read, write, and interpret Attic Greek!
I learned how to read Greek. Furthermore, Professor Robinson did an absolutely excellent job in facilitating learning.
This course provides comprehensive instruction of Ancient Greek as well as grammatical and historical context that is valuable on its own.

This class gives a great foundation in Ancient Greek. I went from knowing none of the alphabet to being able to read all of Plato's Apology in just 3 months. I also gained some interesting linguistics knowledge as well as some historical background for the authors we read.
The ability to read and parse Ancient Greek!

understanding of Greek grammar and baseline understanding of Greek antithetical thought

insight into the context surrounding Plato's "Republic"

explanations of irregular morphemes in Attic Greek due to influence of Indo-European

resources for delving further into Greek

My favorite thing acquired from this class was the method of memorization where I chant verb endings on the way to the dining hall or while I walk my dog.
Understanding of Greek syntax, grammar, and prose structure improved.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I found the structure of this course to be great in that it was difficult, but well paced, with multiple opportunities given to pick up and practice concepts. As long as one is willing to put in a significant amount of time each evening, effectively making Greek 1/6 of their life, they will succeed.

The strengths of this class are many. The grammar portion of the class was very thorough and comprehensive, and the prose composition exercises were extremely helpful in fitting all of the different pieces together. I really enjoyed the drills and exercises we did together in break-out rooms, which were very helpful for solidiyfing concepts. I also liked that we practiced reading Greek out loud together, as this showed me how the language would have sounded when it came to life. We were well-prepared to read the Apology in the latter half of the term  it was truly thrilling to see how far we had come in our study of Greek.

This course is great, honestly there is no way to improve it. And the main reason why is Prof. Robinson. He loves his students and is such an engaging and kind lecturer. He is always super energetic and loves helping his students learn greek. Ive never had a teacher more dedicated to his students than Robinson! Also hes a absolute hoot, so funny  and has great stories. This man is an all around gem!

The course is extremely fast pace and you will definitely need to put in the time and effort to keep up. We went through 18 units in the Hansen & Quinn textbook within the span of 2 months with additional grammar topics sprinkled throughout that were not covered in the textbook. Afterward, we read through the entirety of the Apology in a month which is significantly harder (but doable) than anything seen in the textbook. That being said, the large amount of topics covered in this course makes for an immersive and enriching experience. Despite being difficult, the progress you will make by the end of the semester will be immense. The only weakness of this class is the fact that there really isn't a syllabus until you begin reading the Apology but I don't really think that's the fault of the professor. The rate at which the class goes changes from year to year and Professor Robinson adjusts the schedule based on his assessment of the class and how comfortable everyone is. I personally think that makes the learning even more enriching since he ensures that people are ready and able to move foward.
None. Professor Robinson was outstanding.

Strengths: You will learn a lot if you are in this course. It is an excellent way to get a solid knowledge of the Ancient Greek language. Professor Robinson is also quite (possibly too much so) understanding about absences or unwillingness to translate at a particular time. If he sensed we were getting bored with translation, he would tell us some story or ask a philosophical question about the text, which made it a little less monotonous. Weaknesses: The class can drag on a bit and feel a little monotonous, but it is still worth it. Two hours every morning is a lot, and if possible would be better served by being later in the day. Professor Robinson can also occasionally be a little harsh if you don't understand something quickly, but this doesn't happen too often.
Its a very intense experience! I think it could only be improved if it were offered in person.

Strengths: frequent meetings each week kept the information fresh, and the prose comps were very engaging and helpful applications of what we had learned; also, reading real Greek as a class bolstered our understanding of poetic meter and the flow of Attic Greek.

Weaknesses: not necessary something that could have been helped this year but physically being in a classroom and having to read Greek in the presence of other people (opposed to a screen) would have demanded more confidence and capability
This course is perfectly suited to give students a strong grounding in Greek.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Professor Robinson's use of the Ipad and virtual assignments succeeded.
All covid practices were helpful, especially the use of break-out rooms and Zoom office hours.
It was really well done virtually. Prof Robinson used an iPad as a whiteboard and was super clear.

I think that Professor Robinson did an amazing job in adapting this class in a virtual format. Especially for language courses, virtual teaching is difficult but through careful planning and openness to modifications and changes, Professor Robinson made this class still very enjoyable and worthwhile to take.

This year the professor elected to cancel quizzes and tests due to the stress of the virtual format. While I think this was a good choice, I would urge him to return to using those when in person classes resume, as I think they are valuable motivators for studying.
It might have been nice to have some kind of online anonymous discussion forum to ask questions and such.

Practices that were engaging include the Professor screen-sharing his iPad as he walked through his lectures and the use of breakout rooms to go over homework assignments in smaller groups. Recording the lectures or even merely vital parts of them would have been helpful.
All succeeded.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would. If you want to learn Ancient Greek, I don't think there is a better way than this class. Professor Robinson is an incredibly clear and deep teacher, and he is unbelievably available to help outside of class.

Yes, absolutely! This class will re-shape the way you think about language and introduce you to some of the most beautiful works ever written. No matter what you're studying, you will expand your intellectual horizons by taking this class.
If you want to learn greek 100% take this course! Its a great time and by the end of the semester youve learned so much!

Yes! But make sure you are willing to dedicate yourself to the class. The workload for this class is no joke. Generally, you cover 2 or 3 units a week with around 20-30 vocab words per unit and weekly prose writing assignments on top of that. Plus Ancient Greek is not an easy language either. The amount of grammar that is taught is immense and there are some linguistic topics in between as well. Ancient Greek can be confusing and difficult but Professor Robinson is an absolutely amazing professor! He will ensure that you are on top of the material and is always willing to help you catch up or review any topics. Take this class if you have any interest in Ancient Greek and are looking for an immersive experience! The work is definitely a lot but the amount of knowledge that you will learn will make it worthwhile.

Absolutely. Professor Robinson is a true gem. He obviously loves Greek, antiquity, teaching, and, most of all, he loves his students. He is a truly bright light not just in the classics department but at Yale at large. I am truly honored to have taken a class with professor Robinson.

If a student wants to learn Ancient Greek, I would highly recommend this course. If a student is simply looking to fulfill a language requirement, I think this course is not for them as it is a substantial commitment. I would also caution any student who is planning to take this course to select their other courses carefully, as this will consume much of your time and energy.

If you want to learn Ancient Greek, this is the class to take. You will learn a lot, and the more you apply yourself, the more you will learn. It is not an easy language credit by any means, so only take it if learning Greek is your goal.
Absolutely! It opens up the door to ancient Greek literature! Its intense, but definitely worth the effort!

Absolutely
Professor Robinson is a remarkable teacher both in competency and in humility, and his course includes content and insight that would not easily be found elsewhere. He has a professional understanding of real/natural Greek and goes above and beyond in providing explanations that reach beyond the pages of the textbook. Also, there is never a dull moment once Professor whips out an accent.
Absolutely.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: No other methods were employed
None
non-synchronous reading, memorization, and textbook assignments
Lecture combined with interactive teaching
